title: Das geheime Königreich
text:
Das geheime Königreich ("The Secret Kingdom") is an <a href="opera">opera</a> in one act with words and music by <a href="Ernst%20Krenek">Ernst Krenek</a>, his <a href="Opus%20number">Op</a>. 50 and the second of three one-acters (with "<a href="Der%20Diktator">Der Diktator</a>" and "<a href="Schwergewicht">Schwergewicht, oder Die Ehre der Nation</a>") which premiered on 6 May 1928 at the <a href="Hessisches%20Staatstheater%20Wiesbaden">Hessisches Staatstheater Wiesbaden</a> as part of the <a href="Internationale%20Maifestspiele%20Wiesbaden">Mai-Festwoche Wiesbaden</a>. It is subtitled "" (<a href="fairy-tale%20opera">fairy-tale opera</a> in one act) and has been called a satirical fairy-tale opera.
History.
A note to the press by the publisher <a href="Universal%20Edition">Universal Editio</a> (UE), probably from the end of 1927 and entitled "" (A cycle of one-acters) announces that <a href="Ernst%20Krenek">Ernst Krenek</a> composed three one-act operas after the success of "<a href="Jonny%20spielt%20auf">Jonny spielt auf</a>", to be premiered together at the <a href="Internationale%20Maifestspiele%20Wiesbaden">Festspiele Wiesbaden</a> of 1928. "Das geheime Königreich" is listed as the second of the three, and described as a satirical fairy-tale (Satirisches Märchen). The premiere of the three operas was part of the Mai-Festwoche at the <a href="Hessisches%20Staatstheater%20Wiesbaden">Hessisches Staatstheater Wiesbaden</a> on 6 May 1928. It was the first festival after 1914.
Performances and recordings.
"Das geheime Königreich" was recorded in 1999, conducted by <a href="Marek%20Janowski">Marek Janowski</a>, with <a href="Michael%20Kraus%20%28baritone%29">Michael Kraus</a> as the King and <a href="Claudia%20Barainsky">Claudia Barainsky</a> as the Queen. The opera was coupled with Erich Korngold's "<a href="Der%20Ring%20des%20Polykrates%20%28opera%29">Der Ring des Polykrates</a>" at the <a href="L%C3%BCbeck%20Opera">Lübeck Opera</a> in 2012. A reviewer described the music as intellectual and musical fireworks ("intellektuelles und musikalisches Feuerwerk"), with music at the same time ambitious and effective. He notes similarities to Shakespeare's "<a href="The%20Tempest">The Tempest</a>" and Mozart's "<a href="The%20Magic%20Flute">Die Zauberflöte</a>", with a King who wants to resign after a revolution, and his Jester, and a Queen who falls in love with a revolutionary leader, and is turned into a tree. The same year, it was performed at the <a href="Semperoper">Semperoper</a> in <a href="Dresden">Dresden</a>. A reviewer notes the stories ending about the divinity of a simple creature, and the more complex and darker dimensions ("komplexere, dunklere Dimension") below this surface.
The opera was performed, along with its companion pieces by the <a href="Oper%20Frankfurt">Oper Frankfurt</a> on 30 April 2017, entitled "Drei Opern" (Three operas). The stage director, <a href="David%20Hermann">David Hermann</a>, placed it at the end of the evening, making the King the person who started as the Dictator in the first opera. The conductor was <a href="Lothar%20Zagrosek">Lothar Zagrosek</a>.
